intro: Lithophragma affine subsp. mixtum, commonly known as the mixed trailing phlox, is a low-growing perennial plant native to the western United States. It features trailing stems that produce clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers in shades of pink to purple. The plant has lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive texture. It thrives in well-drained soil and partial to full sunlight, making it suitable for rock gardens or as a ground cover. Its botanical characteristics make it a valuable addition to native plant gardens due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits.
